block.p: Meeting Sailors' Families, Putin Promises Payments President Vladimir V. Putin went to Vidyayevo, the northern base from which the nuclear submarine Kursk made its final voyage two weeks ago, and promised grieving families of the 118-member crew the equivalent of 10 years of an officer's salary each to compensate them for their loss, Russian state television reported.

Putin went to Vidyayevo, the northern base from which the nuclear submarine Kursk made its final voyage two weeks ago, and promised grieving families of the 118-member crew the equivalent of 10 years of an officer's salary each to compensate them for their loss, Russian state television reported.
U.S. Troops Head for Nigeria The first American soldiers are to arrive in Nigeria tomorrow to begin training Nigerian troops as peacekeepers for Sierra Leone.

Protestant Militant Arrested British officials acted against a wave of violence among Protestant paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland by arresting Johnny Adair, a notorious Protestant militant freed 11 months ago under the 1998 Good Friday peace agreement.

Advice for International Bodies President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic, host of next month's meeting of the World Bank and I.M.F., urged international development organizations to heed the ''voices of the people'' for whom they fashion programs, showing more respect for local cultural traditions.

Haggling Over Reparations The work of a United Nations commission that sets compensation for claims arising from the Persian Gulf war has been stymied by a dispute pitting the United States against Russia and France over Kuwait Petroleum's $21.6 billion claim for lost oil and gas sales. The United States endorses the claim.

Church Cutting Budget by 11% The Anglican Church of Canada began reducing spending after an audit said legal fees and settlements arising from charges of abuses at church-run boarding schools would bankrupt the church next year.

Bush Says Data Support His Plan for Tax Cuts Gov. George W. Bush aggressively defended his sweeping tax cut proposal, saying it was both responsible and easily affordable in light of federal surplus projections, and he produced an assortment of figures to show that the plan would not require cuts in government spending.

A Defense of Military Policy Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, a Republican, has rejected criticism by Gov. George W. Bush that the Clinton administration is responsible for a weakened, overextended military, saying post-cold-war cutbacks, begun during Mr. Bush's father's presidency, reflected a strong, bipartisan demand for a ''peace dividend'' now that the United States no longer faced the Soviet Union.

Vice President Al Gore stood before his fellow Veterans of Foreign Wars and rebutted Republican assertions that the readiness and morale of the armed forces had declined during the Clinton administration.

No Special Prosecutor for Gore Attorney General Janet Reno rejected the recommendation of a top Justice Department investigator and will not name a special prosecutor to investigate Vice President Al Gore's political fund-raising activities in 1996, government officials said.
Stay for a Youthful Offender The Georgia Supreme Court stayed the execution of Alexander Williams, 32, who raped and murdered a 16-year-old girl when he was 17.

Mail-Order Business Settles Publishers Clearing House has agreed to pay $18 million to 24 states and the District of Columbia to settle accusations that it uses deceptive promotions to sell magazine subscriptions and collectibles.

Montana Wildfire Measures Gov. Marc Racicot is preparing to restrict access to at least 16 western counties to minimize risk of casualties. The action would put some of Montana's most popular recreation areas off limits until the fires are brought under control.

S.E.C. Drops Inquiry Of Lazio Securities Trades The Securities and Exchange Commission said it would not take action against Representative Rick A. Lazio after concluding a two-month preliminary inquiry into whether he had used inside information to make a series of lucrative trades. The commission would not comment further.

River Search for 2 Boys Two mentally ill teenage boys from a state psychiatric center in Brooklyn were missing in the Hudson near Ossining, N.Y., after they went swimming in a prohibited section during a camping trip, officials said.

Higher Costs for New Stadium Mayor Giuliani said at a groundbreaking ceremony that the city would spend as much as $39 million on a Coney Island stadium for a minor league Mets team -- more than 25 percent more than planned.
Low Scores Prompt Closings Chancellor Harold O. Levy ordered four of the worst-performing city schools shut and a dozen others overhauled because they did not meet state performance standards.
Last Night on the Island ''Survivor,'' the CBS summer reality program that became a cultural phenomenon, comes to an end tonight with a special two-hour finale.
Kennedy Center Honors The Kennedy Center announced recipients of its honors for outstanding American performers, and for the first time most are foreign-born.

Automaker Admits Cover-Up Mitsubishi Motors admitted that it had systematically concealed customer complaints about tens of thousands of defective automobiles since 1977, and it announced recalls of 88,000 vehicles. A month ago, its top executive denied assertions that it had hidden repeated problems.

Interest Rates Left Intact The Fed said wage and price rises appeared to be under control despite robust economic growth, but it warned that it might raise rates later this year if inflation crept up.

Heavy Load for Recalled Tires The Firestone tires that have been failing on Ford Explorers have fairly low weight-carrying capability for a vehicle of the Explorer's size, particularly at the low inflation pressure recommended by Ford, publicly available technical specifications for the tires and the Explorers show.
